If You Forget Me by Pablo Neruda I want you to know one thing. You know how this is: if I look at the crystal moon, at the red branch of the slow autumm at my window, if I touch near the fire the impalpable ash or the wrinkled body of the log, everything carries me to you, as if everything that exists, aromas, light, metals were little boats that sail toward those isles of yours that wait for me. Well, now, if little by little you stop loving me I shall stop loving you little by little. If suddenly you forget me do not look for me, for I shall already have forgotten you. If you think it long and mad, the wind of banners that passes through my life, and you decide to leave me at the shore of the heart where I have roots, remember that on that day, at that hour, I shall lift my arms and my roots will set off to seek another land. But if each day, each hour, you feel that you are destined for me with implacable sweetness, if each day a flower climbs up to your lips to seek me, ah my love, ah my own, in me nothing is extinguished or forgotten, my love feeds on your love, beloved, and as long as you live it will be in your arms without leaving mine. *Thank you Luthien **A companion to urlLink This Is How We End

Across the Nightingale Floor Bumili ako ng bagong libro na nakita ko nung Tuesday siguro mga 3 weeks ago sa National Bookstore. Ito ay ang "Across the Nightingale Floor." Kung mukhang sobrang ina-advertise ko na sya e pasensya na kasi talagang maganda naman ang librong ito. Nabili ko sya for Php539.00. Sulit naman. Hindi ko naiisip na pwede na pala akong makabili ng cd ni Enya or kumain sa Cibo. Ang story ay tunkol sa batang si Takeo na inampon ng isang lord ng Otori na si Shigeru pagkatapos na maligtas ng huli ang bata pagkatapos ma-massacre ng masamang si Iida Sadamu ng Tohan ang village nila. Maganda syang talaga! Descriptive yung novel in the sense na hindi sya na kaka-detract from the story. Minsan kasi may mga novels na sasabihin mong "Pwede ba action na?" Habang binabasa mo sya ay nai-imagine mong naga-unfold sa harap mo ang mga pangyayari. May mga magagandang lines din na makukuha sa librong ito. "I've been overtaken by disaster," she thought at one moment, and at the next, "How can this feeling be a disaster?" "She was what I desired; she would save me from the feeling that I was a living ghost." And more. For reviews, message board on the book and other info, visit urlLink The Otori

One Afternoon It's moments like these that I am glad to be alive. I am watching the sun set. Not as orangey like yesterday. It just passed by 1/8s of the building ahead. Tapos parang cloak nya yung clouds. Ganda talaga. You can't help but notice lalo na at yung rays ng sun e directly tumatama sa mata mo. Parang magandang babae na malayo ang abot ng ganda. Naks. Wala pa akong nakikita o nakikilalang ganun. Sabagay kasi nga naman siguro babae ako at iba ang level of appreciation kesa sa lalaki. Ang ganda talaga. Have you ever felt so happy na iisipin mo pwede ka nang mamatay? Ako hindi pa naman. Aaah masyado na akong nagagalak sa nakikita ko. Hmm...may naisip ako. Sana isang araw may tao na ganito rin ang turing saken. Para syang nanunood ng sunset sa hapon ng 4:59pm and feeling nya at that moment e kuntento na sya sa lahat.

Afternoon Walk Back To Work Sounds, faces. I was aware of them as I was walking on the infernal cobbled steps back to work. Snatches of conversation, the beep-beep of vehicles along Gil Puyat, the sway of branches ahead, the multitude of colors. I feel the muscles of my face lifting. At that moment I was happy. Lost. Invisible. Content to be part of a streaming body going god knows where. "Quite early on I discovered the overlooked space open to those of us with a silent life. I didn't argue with the policeman who said I couldn't cycle over a certain bridge or through a specific gate in the fort - I just stood there, still, until I was invisible, and then I went through. Like a cricket. Like a hidden cup of water. You understand? That is what my brother's public battles taught me." - Kip, The English Patient -

Yuu Watase's "Epotoransu! Mai" Epotoransu! Mai is one of Yuu Watase's (creator of Fushigi Yugi/Ayashi no Ceres) earlier works. It is about Mai , a high schooler, who received an electronic notebook on her 16th birthday. When Mai accidentally typed "Epotoransu", Takuma appeared before her as the being inside the notebook. He then helps Mai win the regard of her school mate, Nimura . I was introduced to Fushigi Yugi then Ayashi no Ceres before this and it came as a breather from the first. Whereas FY and AC have dark and heavy themes, EM is lighthearted and funny, less clingy. The manga was completed after two volumes. The story could've been explored more like maybe Takuma's quest to become a real human being! Takuma over Nimura anytime! Mai is so dense to not notice that when Takuma said "I love you" it was meant even though he took it back because he was just "joking." Sigh. More! More Epotoransu!

Movie Review: HERO Napanood ko ang Hero (Ying Xiong) last week ng Sunday kasama ang aking kapatid na lalake. Ang direktor ng pelikulang ito ay si Zhang Yimou na sya ring nag direct ng Not One Less and The Road Home . Kung nanonood ka ng AXN , you can't miss the last two that I mentioned. Anyway, panoorin nyo ang Hero. Syempre late na itong review ko ano? Kasi naman natabunan na sya sa takilya ng mga bagong movies. Kung maipapalabas man ito ulit dito sa Pinas ay malamang sa Art Film sa Greenbelt o kaya sa Chinese film fest sa Shang, Greenbelt, UP, CCP at iba pa. Magaling sa cinematography ang director na ito. Ah oo nga pala. Bago sya naupo sa director's chair ay cinematographer talaga sya. Ang gumaganap na hero dito ay si Nameless (Jet Li) . Ang storya ay set sa China before the unification meaning bago pa magkaron ng iisang emperor na namumuno sa bansa. Ang ruler ng Qin ang pinakamakapangyarihan sa mga naglalabanang kingdoms sa China kaya may mga gustong pumatay sa kanya. Sinasabi ko na na ito ay SPOILER . Kaya kung kayo ay may balak panoorin ito at sensitive sa spoilers ay lumipat na lang sa ibang site. Tatlong assassins ang nasa top list ng Qin. Si Sky (Donnie Yen) , Broken Sword (Tony Leung) & Flying Snow (Maggie Cheung) . Para lumapit ng 20 paces ang layo from the ruler of Qin, kailangang matalo si Sky. 10 paces pag matalo si Flying Snow and 5 paces (forgive me kung medyo off and paces ko) kapag natalo si Broken Sword. Lahat ang ito ay na-achieve ni Nameless dahil sa pagpapanggap. Tinatamad na akong magkwento. Bakit ko sya nagustuhan? Bukod sa kwento ay dahil nga sa cinematography. Let me enumerate ang mga natatandaan kong scenes: 1. Passing shadow ng clouds on the gray earth with thundering horses' hoofs for background. It seemed to me that the clouds themselves are the ones charging. 2. Synchronized spears of Qin's archers. 3. Fight scene of Nameless and Sky while the old man plays koto in the background. 4. Fight scene of Moon (Zhang Ziyi as Broken Sword's pupil) and Flying Snow. Vivid autumn colors of yellow, orange then finally blood red. I will not even try to compare this movie to Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon . They are both wonderful films. For me there is no comparison or maybe I just love them both.

Yes, yes, I know. My blog is all film schedules and nothing about me or someone else. Ah, well. I hope something big like me going away happens this year. It's a bit like being a coward, I know. Anyway, my goals for until March hopefully will reap desirable results.

Francophonie Film Festival at the Equitable PCI Bank, Tower II To highlight La Journée Internationale de la Francophonie (International Day of the Francophonie), six countries who are members of the Francophonie are sponsoring Le festival des films Francophones (Francophonie Film Festival) from March 17 to 22, 2003 at the Antonio Molina Hall, Equitable PCI Bank, Tower II, Makati Avenue cor H.V. dela Costa St. Makati City. Admission is free on a first-come-first-seated basis. In collaboration with the Manila Chamber Orchestra (MCO) Foundation, Equitable PCI Bank, and Alliance Francaise de Manille, the Embassies of Belgium, Cambodia, Canada, France, Lebanon and Switzerland will be screening award-winning films from their respective countries. Belgium will screen on March 17 at 6:30PM the film "Toto le héros" by Jaco van Dormael. The film tells the story of Thomas and Alfred who were born around the same time. A fire in the nursery had the nurses scrambling to save the newborns. Because he felt that he deserved Alfred's good fortune at being born into a wealthy family, Thomas conceives the idea that he and Alfred were switched at birth, and he can't help seeing that his unhappiness should be Alfred's, from the loss of his sister to his inability to have a relationship with Evelyne. So, as his life is ending, he formulates a plan of revenge against his bitter enemy, his lifetime adversary, the man who stole his existence. On March 18 at 6:30PM, Cambodia will screen "Raja Bori" (Royal City). The film is produced and directed by President of the National Assembly of the Kingdom of Cambodia, His Royal Highness Prince Norodom Ranariddh. Prince Ranariddh produced the film to show the public the rich cultural tradition and heritage of Cambodia. These treasures are the greatest accomplishments of King Jayavarman II and King Suryavarman II, who are the most famous in the history of Angkor and the Khmer Empire. Canada will present "Leolo" , a multi-award winning film by Jean Claude Lauzon, on March 19 at 6:30PM. The film tells the story of Leo who is torn between two worlds - the squalid Montreal tenement that he inhabits with his family, and the imaginative world that he constructs for himself through his writings. His experiences of growing up affect his response to both these worlds. France will screen on March 21 at 6:30PM the film "Metisse" (Café au lait) . In this comedy directed by Mathieu Kassovitz with Julie Mauduech and Hubert Kounde, a beautiful West Indian mulatta named Lola learns that she is pregnant. The question is, who is the father? Excerpt from The Flanders Panel by Arturo Perez-Reverte "The sentence I am now writing is the one that you are now reading." He looked at Belmonte in surprise. "So?" "That's all there is. That sentense was written by me a minute and a half ago and you read it only forty seconds ago. That's to say, my writing and your reading correspond to different moments in time, but on that piece of paper 'now' and 'now' are undoubtedly the same 'now'. Therefore, on the one hand the sentence is true, but on the other hand it lacks all validity. Or is it the concept of time that we're failing to take into account? Don't you think that's a good example of a paradox? I can see you have no answer to it. Well, you'll find the same problem with the enigmas posed by my Van Huys or by anything else. Who's to say that your solution to the problem is the correct one? Your intuition and your system? Fine, but what superior system can you count on to demonstrate that your intuition and your system are valid? And what other system can you call on to corroborate those two systems? As a chess player, I imagine you'll find these lines interesting." The player too is a prisoner of another board Of black nights and of white days. God moves the player and the player the piece. But which god behind God begins the weft Of dust and time and sleep and dying? "The world is just one vast paradox," the old man concluded. "And I defy you to prove the contrary."
